Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 48244-001 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2014 
 
 
 
Developing a Framework for a Liquefied Natural Gas 
Market in Asia
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This  document  is  being  disclosed  to  the  public  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Public 
Communications Policy 2011. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  bcm  –  billion cubic meters 
  IEA  –  International Energy Agency 
  LNG  –  liquefied natural gas 
  mcm  –  million cubic meters 
  mmBtu  –  million British thermal units 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Director General  C. Locsin, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
 
Team leader  A. Jude, Senior Advisor, concurrently Practice Leader (Energy), RSDD 
Team members  C. Torregosa, Senior Energy Officer, RSDD  
  A. Zhou, Senior Energy Specialist, RSDD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Markets in Asia and the Pacific are expected to continue driving the world economy and 
to remain as the world’s energy growth center. The region’s energy consumption increased from 
13% of global consumption in 1971 to 30% in 2013 and is expected to increase to around 44% 
by 2035.1 The current trend is toward burning more fossil fuels to meet demand. However, 
economies like the People’s Republic of China (PRC); India; Japan; the Republic of Korea; and 
Taipei,China  are  looking  at  ways  to  increase  natural  gas  consumption  to  displace  coal 
consumption to improve air quality and, in the case of Japan and the Republic of Korea, to 
displace nuclear-based power generation. 
 
2.  The gas supply agreement between the PRC and Turkmenistan to export 55 billion cubic 
meters (bcm) per annum of natural gas through Kazakhstan is a milestone achievement. Hence, 
regional cooperation and integration is an important tool for energy trade and is a strategic 
agenda and core area of operations of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) under its Strategy 
20202. In April 2014, the Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 affirmed ADB’s commitment to 
regional cooperation and integration with “greater attention to trade facilitation and capacity 
building.”3 This greater  attention  will  constitute  “dedicated  support for trade facilitation  and 
harmonization of standards and practices to help boost competitiveness” (footnote 2). As a 
result of persistent market supply constraints, infrastructure bottlenecks, and trade inefficiencies, 
liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices in the region are two to four times higher than prices in 
Europe and the United States. The technical assistance (TA) will develop a framework for 
establishing a competitive LNG market in Asia.4  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Asian gas market comprises mature markets (Japan; the Republic of Korea; and 
Taipei,China),  energy  giants  still  developing  their  gas  markets  (the  PRC  and  India),  and 
developing markets (Southeast Asian markets). The region’s gas consumption is growing much 
faster than the worldwide average, with developing member countries in the region increasingly 
reliant on imported LNG and projected to largely remain so for the foreseeable future. Future 
Asian natural gas demand depends heavily on the price of natural gas relative to coal and on 
the development of sufficient regional conventional and unconventional supplies. Natural gas 
imports are more expensive than the wholesale prices in many Asian countries, which have a 
long history of price subsidies (both for oil and natural gas). Moreover, Asian gas prices are not 
reflective of the regional supply–demand fundamentals of natural gas, but are linked to long-
term supply contracts for crude oil.   
 
 
4. Long-term Asian LNG prices were at record highs in 2012 and 2013, hovering around 
$20/million British thermal units (mmBtu) to $18/mmBtu. During January–October 2014, the spot 
LNG prices were about $10.4/mmBtu; they have currently increased to $14.5/mmBtu due to 
increased demand from Japan and the Republic of Korea. LNG is mostly supplied to Asian 
consumers under long-term contracts. The recent slide in Brent prices to below $80 a barrel 
could prompt some Asian buyers to call on additional long-term supplies where possible. LNG 
imports are becoming less affordable for some countries, and an insufficient gas supply could 
                                                
1  ADB. 2013. Energy Outlook for Asia and the Pacific. Manila.  
2  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020:  The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank 2008-2010. 
Manila 
3  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 November 2014.

2   
seriously damage economic growth rates in a region where millions of people still lack access to 
modern energy. 
 
5.  LNG  markets  responded  to  growing  demand  by  bringing  new  investment  forward, 
especially in Australia, but recent experience has been plagued by project delays and cost 
overruns. Given its abundant shale gas production, North America emerged as a credible 
potential new supplier. However, the greenfield developments in Canada appear to have high 
cost. Regulatory approval processes and social acceptance of greenfield shale gas and oil 
development have delayed the envisaged flow of gas to Asian markets, which despite its low 
production cost will not going to be cheap in Asia due to the significant infrastructure needed. 
Similarly, the long arduous approvals of export licenses in the United States (US) as well as the 
fundamental project development time lag have impacted gas flow to Asian markets. While 
demand is rising in Asia, US gas will reach Asia markets only in early 2016 and in significant 
quantities only after 2025. Meanwhile, Canadian natural gas development will take time and is 
not likely to reach Asian markets before 2020. Even in 2035, North American LNG is not 
projected to exceed 10% of total gas supply in Asia. 
 
6.  The International Energy Agency (IEA) projects that the US will become the third largest 
exporter of gas after Qatar and Australia. As North American LNG flows to Japan and the 
Republic  of  Korea,  the  Japanese  and  Koreans  will  buy  less  LNG  from  Qatar  and  other 
conventional exporters, releasing LNG for other markets. LNG deliveries in 2013 amounted to 
240 million tons (100.8 million cubic meters [mcm]). Since 2012, LNG supply has been plagued 
by production shortfalls and supply shocks. The flat supply of gas and rising Asian demand 
have resulted in continued tightening of the gas market, despite increased production from 
Algeria,  Angola,  Australia,  Malaysia,  Qatar,  and  Yemen.  Algerian  production  was  low  and 
Angola had delays in plant start-up. Unplanned gas outages in Nigeria and continued production 
decline  in  Egypt  weighed  on  gas  supply  and  kept  overall  gas  supplies  flat.  IEA  projects 
worldwide LNG trade will increase by 40% to 450 bcm by 2019. Driving this growth are markets 
in the PRC, Japan, India, the Republic of Korea, and Southeast Asian countries. US LNG 
exports will probably climb to about 2.41 bcm/day in 2020 or about 1.8% of global demand. 
While the US will not begin exporting gas until late 2015, the prospect of rising North American 
supply is already having an impact as the market anticipates increased competition. Suppliers 
like Qatar are looking to balance their portfolios and positioning themselves to be able to offer 
Asian buyers a much more flexible supply option from a pricing perspective.  
 
7.  Ten  new  regasification  terminals  started  operations  in  2013,  while  four  new  LNG 
importing markets emerged: Indonesia, Israel, Malaysia, and Singapore. Viet Nam is building a 
regasification  terminal  to  meet  gas  demand  for  power  generation  and  the  petrochemical 
industry. In 2013, imports to Asia increased, albeit at a slower rate than in recent years with a 
rise of 4.8 mcm. This tempering of growth was primarily due to Japan approaching a ceiling on 
both volume of LNG imports it can physically accommodate and the capacity of its combined-
cycle gas turbine power station. Japan’s import of LNG in 2015 is difficult to estimate as some of 
the nuclear plants are likely to come on line and this could free up some spare LNG capacity to 
other Asian markets like the PRC, India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand. 
 
8.  While North American LNG supplies are being developed, supplies from Papua New 
Guinea (2.9 mcm/annum) and Australia (where new LNG trains entered into construction to 
supply 25.2 mcm/annum) could help meet the demand, but the timing of this new capacity will 
be key to meeting the market supply over the next few years. The early supply of LNG from 
Papua New Guinea on the spot market lowered the spot market gas price in early 2014 but has 
risen as new long-term contracts were negotiated. Additionally, gas has an important transition

3 
role in developing countries as a lower emission fuel than other fossil fuels used for power 
generation. In this context, transparent, efficient, and well-functioning markets are an important 
tool to ensure that natural gas secures its place in the energy mix. 
 
9.  Without a transparent gas price that reflects regional supply and demand fundamentals, 
gas producers will have more difficulty signaling scarcity situations. This can result in a slower 
market response to (unexpected) gas shortages and therefore forms a security-of-supply risk. 
This risk has given rise to recent discussions of the need for a regional LNG trading hub that 
can facilitate the move of Asian gas importers away from oil-linked long-term contracts and 
toward gas-to-gas pricing models. IEA examined this in 2012 and concluded that the transition 
from oil-indexed, long-term contracts to hub-based spot pricing is likely to be slow and gradual. 
 
III.  THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be a competitive, market-based LNG subsector fostered in 
Asia. The  outcome  will  be  increased  understanding  and  appreciation  by  target  developing 
member countries of efficient functioning natural gas markets in Asia. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have seven outputs. 
 
12.  Situation analysis of the current gas market in selected countries completed. The 
current situation of different Asian countries will be analyzed in depth, to identify necessary 
steps for the countries to liberalize their gas markets and create an enabling environment for a 
regional gas hub focusing on required regulatory, pricing, and governance structures. This will 
involve  an  examination  of  projected  supply  and  demand,  gas  market  regulation,  market 
stakeholders, existing and planned gas infrastructure developments, existing supply contracts, 
and subsidies. Given the relative market size of the PRC and India, the study will develop a 
separate chapter dedicated to demand, pipeline facilities (bottlenecks), pricing, and regulatory 
reforms needed in their gas subsectors, as well as the prospects for gas displacing coal. 
Indonesia and Malaysia will also be treated as a separate case, as they are transforming from 
LNG exporters to LNG exporters and importers, and have access to pipeline infrastructure in the 
Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Third-party access to this pipeline infrastructure will be 
examined along with regulatory challenges to be addressed for the network to operate. The 
analysis will include lessons from the experience and operation of trading hubs in North America 
and Europe, as well as how and in what ways political interference and economic cooperation 
have affected, positively or not, the establishment and operation of these gas-trading hubs. 
  
13.  Supply-side analysis completed. Existing long-term contracts of each country will be 
reviewed considering their flexibility, duration, pricing indexation, whether they are delivery ex-
ship or free on board, and how they compete against Henry Hub prices in different pricing 
scenarios. 5 Potential future suppliers to the region will be examined, and existing and future 
LNG export projects in each of these regions analyzed, including how they are contracted, their 
proposed timelines, and the relationship between potential suppliers and the various Asian 
countries in terms of investment. The analysis will include an examination of how exogenous 
                                                
5  The Henry Hub is a natural gas distribution hub in the United States and its name is used as the pricing point for 
gas futures contracts traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

4   
supply-side developments (e.g., the potential for floating LNG technology to increase supply, 
development of shale gas resources, or LNG export policies of suppliers) may impact the 
potential for Asia to create a natural gas trading hub. Options will be examined for accessing 
stranded  gas  in  Indonesia.6 The  supply  and  demand-side  studies  will  assess  the  volume 
required to ensure the regional trading hub is competitive taking into consideration all variables 
of markets in the region, supply chains, and flows within and outside the region including 
existing institutional arrangements (e.g., long-term supply contracts).  
 
14.  Demand-side analysis completed. The existing demand and major markets for LNG in 
the region will be examined, as well as potential and emerging markets. A model will be 
developed to identify projects in the future, and demand by year and by country, considering all 
variables, such as power and industrial requirements for gas in each country. 
 
15.  Shipping analyzed. Given that transport costs are a significant part of final LNG costs, 
shipping supply chain businesses will be interviewed to determine trends and changing market 
dynamics for LNG transport. The task includes examination of the outlook for LNG carrier day 
rates, the impact of shipping rates on LNG prices, adequacy of transport infrastructure and 
future requirements to support the Asian LNG market, and impacts such as the impact of 
Panama Canal expansion and changes to average shipping distance with the emergence of 
North America as a major LNG supplier to the region. 
 
16.  Local conditions analyzed. Development of LNG supply in the region must consider 
smaller LNG cargo size requirements and the need to have anchor customers that can afford 
new LNG supplies and support adequate LNG infrastructure. The analysis will include small-
scale LNG for small power markets and the transport sector in Indonesia where coal-mining 
companies use dual fuel (diesel and gas) for large dump trucks and gas in gas engines for 
power  generation.  The  many  high  carbon  dioxide  gas  fields  and  stranded  gas  fields  in 
Southeast Asia must also be assessed. Recommendations will be made on whether developing 
small-scale and floating LNG markets makes technical and economic sense, and what the 
impact might be on the creation of an Asian market if such technology was developed. The 
potential of floating storage regasification unit technology in the region will be considered, as 
well  as  trans-Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  gas  pipeline  infrastructure  as  an 
alternative to regional LNG trade.  
 
17.  Environmental and security impacts assessed, including interactions between the 
power and gas subsectors. Pricing of natural gas and its resultant competitiveness with coal is 
essential to determine the projected gas demand from the power generation system, the largest 
source of LNG demand across all countries under study. The assessment will address the 
question of how the creation of an Asian natural gas trading hub would affect gas prices and, 
consequently, how lower prices might affect choices about energy generation and climate policy 
design. Of particular interest is the contribution that an efficiently functioning gas market can 
make to the political economy of climate policy, by enabling diversification from new coal 
investments, increasing energy security, or increasing energy access without undue costs. It will 
also analyze the potential substitution effects that reduced prices from gas trading might yield, 
and provide recommendations on how to enhance the role of natural gas in power generation, 
analyzing its competitiveness against coal in different scenarios. 
 
18.  Structural  requirements  for  creating  a  trading  hub  identified.  International 
experience of commodity market experts and practitioners will be utilized to determine how to 
                                                
6  Stranded gas refers to natural gas reserves that are too small to be developed economically.

5 
operationalize a spot market for natural gas trading in Asia. The key questions to be addressed 
are (i) what sort of liquidity, transparency, and diversification are necessary to allow the price 
discovery that is a necessary ingredient for an Asian natural gas spot market; (ii) what are the 
technical steps required to achieve that liquidity; and (iii) what kind of regulatory environment 
needs to be put in place. Recommendations will be developed on how to proceed through the 
technical steps required to establish a trading hub, as well as examine the potential physical 
locations for a hub. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.2 million, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ADB will be the executing agency through the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department. A team of international consultants, comprising IEA experts will be engaged to 
implement the TA activities. 
 
21.  The TA will be implemented from January 2015 to June 2016. Thirty-six person-months 
of international consulting services will be engaged through single-source selection.7 ADB will 
directly engage IEA, according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended 
from time to time). Single-source selection is justified given the complex and specialized nature 
of the assignment and given IEA’s substantial work on past issues and challenges faced by 
Asian  markets  through  its  various  studies,  including  Natural  Gas  in  India  (2010)8 and 
Developing a Natural Gas Trading Hub in Asia (2013).9 Importantly, IEA has neutrality with 
regard to gas market outcomes and the establishment of a regional gas hub, and the ability to 
engage market players objectively in regional forums. In this context, IEA is well respected by 
governments, and multilateral and bilateral agencies active in the energy sector.  
 
22.  The TA will be administered by the Sustainable Infrastructure Division, with guidance 
from the Office of the Director General, Regional and Sustainable Development Department. 
The TA will be regularly monitored through assessment of quality, alignment with proposed 
outcome, and timely delivery of outputs. Overall TA results will be disseminated through the 
release of outputs to national governments and through regional energy forums and the energy 
community of practice. Knowledge products may be produced based on the study reports and 
the TA completion report, which will document the implementation of the TA, lessons, and 
effective methodologies. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis 
for Developing a Framework for a Liquefied Natural Gas Market in Asia, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board. 
                                                
7  The IEA contract amount will be limited to $930,000 with the Regional and Sustainable Development Department 
facilitating the regional workshops. 
8  IEA. 2010. Natural Gas in India, Working Paper. Paris. 
9  IEA. 2013. Developing a Natural Gas Trading Hub in Asia. Paris.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.   The international consultant will have expertise in (i) economic and geopolitical aspects 
of the natural gas market in Asia; (ii) global natural gas trading, contracting, and market delivery 
structures; (iii) policy, legal, and regulatory issues; and (iv) administration and logistics related to 
research publication. An output-based contract with lump-sum out of pocket expenses may be 
considered to reduce administrative burden and improve economy, efficiency, and value for 
money aspects of the TA. 
 
2.   Project manager (international, 9 person-months). The project manager will manage 
the study on a day-to-day basis in terms of coordinating inputs from team members, liaising with 
the project leads of other research institutes and partners, and contributing to drafting of the 
reports. The manager will have related qualifications and particular expertise in natural gas 
markets and trading, and will draw on analytic capabilities provided by other staff. Specifically, 
the project manager will  
(i)  build and leverage deep relationships in the finance and commodities industries 
to answer detailed questions relating to the creation and operation of an Asian 
gas trading hub; 
(ii)  generate  original  and  unique  insights  about  the  market  conditions  that  are 
required to allow the emergence of spot trading activity for gas;  
(iii)  coordinate with regional think tanks, such as International Energy Economics of 
Japan; and oil and gas companies, such as Kogas, Tokyo Gas, GAIL, Petronas, 
Pertamina,  and  PTT  to  get  a  better  sense  of  the  gas  supply  and  demand 
situation; 
(iv)  assess how investment by regional companies in North American shale gas and 
Australian gas development will affect regional gas prices when the gas becomes 
available; 
(v)  undertake interviews with market participants and regulators in the United States 
(US) as well as throughout Asia, in addition to other global experts on gas trading, 
price formation, and commodity flows; and 
(vi)  provide inputs into developing a regional gas hub  (e.g., on how Henry Hub 
pricing emerged, how such a mechanism can be developed for Asia, and which 
region in Asia would be best suited to hosting such a gas hub).  
 
3.   Principal investigator (international, 4 person-months). The investigator will draw on 
significant senior energy and gas market experience in government, think tanks, and the private 
sector and work to maximize the policy impact of the study and its outputs. Specific tasks 
include 
(i)  assist in coordinating the full project team and coordinate with  the research 
teams, 
(ii)  serve as the primary point of contact for ADB, 
(iii)  set a delivery schedule for proposed outputs, 
(iv)  lead international workshops,  
(v)  guide the structure and development of written products, and  
(vi)  sign off on final outputs.  
 
4.   Senior gas market analysts (up to five international experts, 18 person-months in total). 
The senior gas market analysts form the core of the team and will support analysis of the 
economic and geopolitical impacts of the changing Asian gas market, drawing upon experience 
in developing policy recommendations for countries to help implement the changes needed to

Appendix 3  11 
build a successful LNG hub. The experts should have (i) a degree in energy economics; (ii) a 
minimum  of  10  years’  work  experience  in  energy  markets,  notably  global  gas  markets;  
(iii) experience in leading projects involving multicultural teams; and (iv) experience in working 
with government and energy companies as well as providing advice on key energy issues. 
Major tasks include  
(i)  analyze  and  understand  the  challenges  faced  by  gas  markets  in  different 
countries,  including  by  conducting  interviews  and  reviews  of  the  countries 
(People’s Republic of China [PRC], India, Indonesia, Japan, the Republic of 
Korea, and Malaysia) included in the study; 
(ii)  analyze  the  economic  and  geopolitical  changes  that  would  stem  from  the 
creation of an Asian LNG hub; 
(iii)  assess if the hub could be in the PRC or Japan instead of Singapore, as the 
volume of LNG landed in Japan is 4.5 times the volume in Singapore; identify 
other measures that need to be in place when setting up an LNG hub; 
(iv)  given agreements signed for exports from the Russian Federation into the PRC, 
examine if the gas volume imported via pipeline from the Myanmar, Russian 
Federation, and Turkmenistan, and the imported LNG are sufficient to meet the 
PRC’s demand; if not, how much more is this demand expected to increase; 
(v)  as the PRC has ongoing shale gas exploration by Shell and Total through joint 
ventures, will the application of new technology and drilling methods result in the 
PRC becoming a large shale gas producer by 2020, and if so, how is this likely to 
change the regional gas markets in Asia and shale gas exports out of North 
America; 
(vi)  build upon earlier work done in the PRC on gas pricing and regulation, and 
recommend appropriate policies needed to support domestic gas exploration and 
domestic market demand in the power subsector, combined-heat and power, 
industrial demand, and domestic gas use for cooking; 
(vii)  analyze the gas market in the PRC, including barriers to PRC shale development 
that  are  geologic,  technological,  and  institutional  in  nature;  the  potential  for 
pricing structures and mineral rights reform to support domestic production; and 
infrastructure (pipeline) constraints; 
(viii)  assess the implications of LNG exports from the United States (US) on Asian gas 
prices when US gas becomes available in 2016; determine the pricing that is 
being used in this context and what is needed in Asia to move away from gas 
price linked to oil to purely gas–gas price; 
(ix)  with  new  LNG  supplies  coming  into  the  market  from  Algeria,  Australia, 
Mozambique, North America, and Papua New Guinea, assess how the price of 
LNG from Qatar will be affected, and if Qatar will be more amenable to lowering 
its price to secure markets;  
(x)  assuming the Iran and United States are able to resolve their issues on nuclear, 
assess if the US will allow Iran to export gas and, if so, how will this affect the 
supply and demand situation in the region; 
(xi)  examine the use of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) gas 
pipeline  for  export  through  pipeline  to,  for  example,  Singapore  via  the  gas 
pipeline network from  Myanmar or Viet Nam;  
(xii)  identify the challenges to having third-party access to this gas pipeline network in 
ASEAN and what kinds of policy and legal regulations are needed to enable such 
cross-border gas flows; draw upon European experience and determine if this 
can be adopted after modification to suit ASEAN needs; 
(xiii)  identify the impediments in Indonesia for allowing third party access in its gas 
pipelines and recommend appropriate changes in policy or regulation that could

12  Appendix 3 
be  implemented  by  Indonesia  so  that  more  domestic  gas  could  be  used 
domestically instead of exported; 
(xiv)  identify  policy,  regulations,  and  incentives  needed  to  bring  stranded  gas  to 
market in Indonesia; assess if this gas can be used in some areas of Kalimantan 
and Sumatra to meet localized loads; identify financial and technical resources 
needed to bring this gas for consumption; 
(xv)  identify the role of floating LNG and floating regasification and storage units in 
ASEAN,  and  their  cost  advantage  over  land-based  LNG  terminals;  provide 
examples of how these can be used or are already being used;  
(xvi)  identify  the  challenges  in  India  and  what  is  preventing  the  construction  of 
pipelines and LNG terminals on the eastern side of the country; 
(xvii)  assess how gas pricing and regulation is addressed in India, and if this can be 
improved and, if so, make salient recommendations; 
(xviii)  examine specifics of LNG markets in Asia, in terms of sourcing (analysis of long-
term LNG contracts), key terms in long-term LNG contracts, and LNG shipping; 
examine the flexibility of moving shipments from one intended country to another 
during shipment; 
(xix)  provide  guidance  to  other  team  members  and  participants  on  each  of  the 
different steps of the study; and 
(xx)  review the draft reports, participate in the debriefings of the research team, and 
assist with report dissemination as required. 
 
5.   Publications expert (international, 2 person-months). The expert will have qualifications 
in communications, public relations, or a related field, and will 
(i)  support the development of the reports and all related public materials; 
(ii)  support the scoping and drafting of final outputs; 
(iii)  copy edit reports; and 
(iv)  write press releases, executive summaries, fact sheets, opinion editorials, blog 
posts, and other short-form outputs that maximize the visibility and accessibility 
of the research. 
 
6.   Project administration expert (international, 3 person-months). The expert will support 
the project from an administrative perspective, specifically  
(i)  work with  research counterparts to get final contracts executed,  
(ii)  organize meetings, travel and logistics for project staff, 
(iii)  manage  all  subcontracts  of  the  agreement  and  work  with  the  relevant 
government offices to ensure protocol is followed for the project in each country, 
(iv)  process  reimbursements  and  invoices  for  research  team  staff  and  complete 
related work, and 
(v)  organize  and  manage  private  workshops  and  public  release  events  in 
coordination with the publications expert and ADB to ensure proper protocol is 
followed for all final report releases.

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  bcm  –  billion cubic meters 
  IEA  –  International Energy Agency 
  LNG  –  liquefied natural gas 
  mcm  –  million cubic meters 
  mmBtu  –  million British thermal units 
  PRC  –  People’s Republic of China 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Director General  C. Locsin, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD) 
 
Team leader  A. Jude, Senior Advisor, concurrently Practice Leader (Energy), RSDD 
Team members  C. Torregosa, Senior Energy Officer, RSDD  
  A. Zhou, Senior Energy Specialist, RSDD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
